item.title:
A Russian military convoy, no less than 60km long, has been moving at snail’s pace towards Kyiv thanks to botched logistics and fierce Ukrainian resistance.
But read why the respite could be temporary ⬇️
Russia’s financial woes are not yet as severe as in 1998, when the rouble plunged by 70%. But another debt default could be similarly devastating https://t.co/lfcPUBpyp0

Vladimir Putin claims that his “special military operation” is going “to plan”. It isn't. Why won't Russia leave its neighbour alone?
Read our latest analysis on the invasion: https://t.co/Ku48sueqh2 https://t.co/AKN9hFx2Jk
NATO can and should do more to support Ukraine. But imposing a no-fly zone would be wrong-headed https://t.co/HJ1wgnBHfp
The sanctions sword is double-edged: it encourages those who fear them to develop alternative financial and technological infrastructures https://t.co/DheAeGs1qB

“He’s gone from coercion...to punishment. I think he thinks, at this point now, if he can’t get Ukraine, he’s pretty much going to destroy it.” Foreign-affairs specialist Fiona Hill assesses Vladimir Putin’s motivations in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/IsWOwImgLS https://t.co/B3xFzxBxpw
“Everywhere that women start to get educated and start to get options the age of marriage goes up,” says Stephanie Coontz, an author on the subject https://t.co/e0eHaxHNpW

Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine is driving its people to the country’s western borders. So far the majority have headed to Poland, which is opening its arms to the newcomers https://t.co/BD872Lub60 https://t.co/yCy3fKLxKI
The military difficulties the Russians are having may lead China to rethink the feasibility of an invasion across the Taiwan strait https://t.co/rGcA1aE6ao

“There's nothing special about me. The only thing that’s different in my story is that my father did not stop me.”
To mark #IWD2022, @Malala and @zannymb discuss how to improve the lives of girls everywhere.
Subscribers can sign up to watch here: https://t.co/Cg6G1x8syd https://t.co/S6leRxz0Jo
From war photography to the Ukrainian flag, we walk you through how we chose this week’s cover image https://t.co/rIEDW4sHEu
How do Western countries hope to influence Russia’s behaviour by wielding sanctions against its economy? https://t.co/NytCWKrPDt https://t.co/urHdrQz0PU
Europe is going through a watershed moment https://t.co/sI7qgkwaeM
Xi Jinping faces a dilemma. Though he does not want Vladimir Putin to fail, helping him means being spattered by his carnage https://t.co/CNPn7zq08z
No major economy in the modern world has ever been hit so hard by sanctions https://t.co/E78v6VXx2f

The world must be willing to bleed Vladimir Putin’s regime of the resources that enable him to wage war and abuse his own people even if that imposes costs on Western economies https://t.co/EkCvY3QilB
The West has deployed an economic weapon that was until recently unthinkable. It must be used wisely https://t.co/4zlShQ2Qun
Russia faces a deep recession. But rather than relent, Vladimir Putin may double down on his attempts to cut the country off from the outside world https://t.co/8dOAIOvIA8
The closer you look, the clearer it is that a no-fly zone would not only fail to bring about the defeat of Vladimir Putin's armies, but would also court catastrophe https://t.co/QXMRYhyVnW
There is a world of difference between diplomatic and logistical support for Ukraine and outright combat with Russia https://t.co/GY93JSrWaC
Watching a prolonged and bloody siege of Kyiv would further enrage public opin­ion in large parts of the world, and could thus lead to even harsher sanctions on Russia https://t.co/bd1pxQmsrl

“Any messenger bringing bad information would certainly be facing the ‘shoot-the-messenger’ principle.” Foreign-affairs specialist Fiona Hill describes Vladimir Putin’s silencing of opposition within his inner circle, on “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/rG9unuH1Sk
Cults have hierarchical structures, their own jargon and are stuffed with weirdos. Sound familiar? https://t.co/XamuoK5hse
American officials think the relationship between Russia and China will allow them to fuse their alliances in Europe and Asia into a stronger whole https://t.co/gjk9GaKFXT
Any Russian economic response to sanctions must be met by more damaging measures by the West that make that act of retaliation irrational https://t.co/VHj0nrxPa5

Russia, one economist says, is sliding back into the dark post­-So­viet 1990s, the dismal period which Vladimir Putin says was forced on it by the West and from which he liberated it https://t.co/gJqDGoVa4F

The idea that Vladimir Putin would carry out his threat to use battlefield nuclear weapon is surely unlikely. Unfortunately, it is not impossible: he has just invaded his neighbour https://t.co/t3r6lAIw5O

“If you start an operation on flawed assumptions, inevitably, your planning is inadequate—your command and control won’t work.” General Sir Nick Carter joins “The Economist Asks” to explain how Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has not gone to plan https://t.co/hsMxdYAwAP

“Western politicians danced with Vladimir Putin (some of them literally) and retired to chair the boards of Russian companies,” writes Ingrida Simonyte. “These firms funded the Kremlin’s arms race and diverted billions to Mr Putin’s entourage” https://t.co/cVlaJfur2S
British people appear to want extremely harsh asylum rules by default, but generous exceptions for groups that have captured their sympathy https://t.co/Ilya46W2TU
Each time we took something away from the design, it became stronger. All that was left was the suffering https://t.co/pgPHEUTBCg

He insists that the world back off while he sharpens his knife and sets about his slaughter. Other countries must stand up to him https://t.co/9dKM5oV1IA

Kyiv looks likely to be encircled and then presumably besieged https://t.co/FmnYnUqCcC
After a prolonged isolationist funk, Republicans have rejoined the internationalist mainstream on this issue. And in doing so they have turned from Donald Trump https://t.co/sCIgYdvNf5

Joe Biden and his foreign policy team should “take the credit for this impressive and united NATO response to Putin’s agressions”. Hear more from @JamesMAstill on our “Checks and Balance” podcast https://t.co/j8geYqtYJe https://t.co/kKe1w8C516

Ukraine has “an incredible spirit of independence”, says @yermolenko_v. “This spirit has been there for centuries but is showing itself now in full strength. Freedom is the key trait of Ukraine’s identity as a political nation” https://t.co/6InsLy4IIt

Russia always assumed that it would be able to access foreign exchange to defend the rouble. Being shut out of the SWIFT financial-transfer system will hurt trade. The question is whether Vladimir Putin cares https://t.co/DpQq9w4fkx

Europe is grinding through gears it did not know it had. Later it will ask itself where it went wrong, what mistakes landed Europe in the terrible crisis that is suddenly changing everything https://t.co/kYzPxu5MYa

From the start, he has made clear that this is a war of escalation. He threatens to be more destructive even if that means resorting to a nuclear weapon. The world must stand up to him https://t.co/nGIovkaKWK

“He’s been absolutely phenomenal in raising national morale. There’s admiration for what he’s done and is achieving.” General Sir Nick Carter assesses President Volodymyr Zelensky’s leadership during the war in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/tjVn70ZQzT https://t.co/iLHPNiBMZs

“If the goal of the West’s economic war is to end [Vladimir] Putin’s war of aggression in Ukraine, then historical experience suggests different measures will be needed,” argues Nicholas Mulder, an assistant history professor who studies sanctions https://t.co/RAlKmucuij
“We respect the calm and the strength of the Ukrainian people. We are with you”—Nobel laureates’ open letter in support of Ukraine https://t.co/NnJaefrd3h

In French eyes, the war in Ukraine exposes the need for Europe to reinforce its strategic capacity. Meanwhile three of Emmanuel Macron’s rivals want to pull France out of NATO’s integrated military command https://t.co/iZdBphmYMc

More Russians are asking Google “how to leave Russia” than have done so in the last 18 years since such data became public. We used search data from the country to track discontent: https://t.co/t99bflGx95
